metadata.feature_description: Caches GTM script template from configuration file to improve performance

observations: Configuration Caching is a system-level automatic feature with NO direct UI elements available for testing.

Code analysis of TagManagerModule.cs (lines 65-78) reveals the caching implementation: The GTM script template is cached using DataCache.GetCache('GoogleTagManagerScript') and DataCache.SetCache() with a DNNCacheDependency on the GoogleTagManager.config file.

The cache key 'GoogleTagManagerScript' is hardcoded and the caching operates transparently within the HttpModule pipeline - there is no admin interface to view cache status, clear the cache, or observe cache hit/miss statistics.

All suggested test scenarios require backend access not available via UI: (1) 'Verify script template is cached on first access' requires cache inspection API, (2) 'Test cache invalidation on config file change' requires file system modification during runtime and cache inspection, (3) 'Verify cache dependency on GoogleTagManager.config' requires backend debugging, (4) 'Test performance with cached vs uncached template' requires sub-millisecond timing measurements, (5) 'Verify cache works across multiple requests' requires cache state inspection.

POTENTIAL BUG FOUND: In TagManagerModule.cs lines 74-77, the cache is only set when scriptContent is null or empty: 'if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(scriptContent)) { DataCache.SetCache(...) }'. This appears to be a logic error - the condition should likely be '!string.IsNullOrEmpty(scriptContent)' to cache valid content rather than empty content.

The GoogleTagManager.config file contains the ScriptTemplate with placeholders [CONTAINERID], [USETAGMANAGERFORGA], and [DATALAYER_INIT] that are replaced at runtime before injection into the page head element.
Per testing philosophy: 'Feature exists in code but not visible in UI - Do NOT create a test for it.' This feature is purely backend infrastructure with no UI interaction points.
